Name: Jar
Description: Buff-coloured pottery vessel with rounded base, small looped handles for suspension cords, wide mouth with pronounced rim. This vessel was excavated at the key early settlement near Kom el-Ahmar (the Hierakonpolis of later texts) in southern Upper Egypt. The burial goods date this tomb to the end of the Naqada II Period, on the eve of the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt in the final stage of state formation. During this period Kom el-Ahmar was a major centre of the emerging Egyptian kingship.
